references: Counterfactuals generated in FL have similar quality to the ones in CL. (Table 1) Unlike Local CL, FL leverages information from all clients, thereby producing counterfactuals that more accurately reflect non-IID clients’ data. As shown in Table 1, FL achieves higher validity compared to the Local CL approach, indicating that the FL’s counterfactuals better match ground-truth labels. Additionally, FL exhibits lower sparsity, which measures the number of modifications needed to achieve the counterfactuals. Table 1 shows these results using a counterfactual generator we adapted for this scenario (see Appendix A.2), however, similar conclusions are also obtained using out-of-the-box generators [34] (see Appendix B).

references: To explore the independence of Federated Behavioural Planes (FBPs) from the counterfactual generator, we evaluate our methodology with an alternative model named VCNet [34], maintaining identical experimental conditions. As illustrated in Table 2, VCNet achieves comparable performance in both Federated Learning (FL) and Centralised Learning (CL) configurations, where data from all clients is placed on a single machine. Similarly to our counterfactual generator, the results demonstrate that the privacy-preserving training strategy (i.e., FL) does not compromise the VCNet’s effectiveness compared to the ideal CL condition. Operating under similar privacy constraints, FL enables VCNet to learn from the diverse distributions of client data, thereby surpassing the performance of the Local CL approach, where each client independently trains their own model.

A2.T3.caption: Table 3: Comparison of our Federated Behavioural Shields across across five attacks types—No attack, Crafted-noise, Inverted-gradient, Label-flipping, Inverted-loss—on Breast Cancer dataset for both IID and non-IID configurations
A2.T3.table:
Condition No attack MP Noise MP I.Grad DP Flip DP I.Loss Mean
non-IID 95.7±plus-or-minus\pm1.1 98.0±plus-or-minus\pm0.8 95.3±plus-or-minus\pm0.7 94.2±plus-or-minus\pm0.6 95.9±plus-or-minus\pm0.9 95.8±plus-or-minus\pm0.4
IID 98.2±plus-or-minus\pm0.3 98.43±plus-or-minus\pm0.4 98.2±plus-or-minus\pm0.2 96.4±plus-or-minus\pm0.9 93.7±plus-or-minus\pm1.0 97.0±plus-or-minus\pm0.4
references: In our main study, we focus on the non-IID setting, which is the most prevalent scenario for cross-silo FL in practice [39]. This setting presents considerable challenges due to the substantial differences between updates from honest clients, which can obscure the divergent behaviours of malicious clients [40]. Consequently, we conducted experiments on the Breast Cancer dataset in both IID and non-IID settings using our FBPs for comparative analysis. As depicted in Figure 9, we initially visualized client trajectories on both behavioural planes and within the counterfactual distance space l𝑙l (defined in Equation 6). The trajectories illustrate the uniform nature of honest client behaviors on both planes, distinctly highlighting the divergent behavior of the malicious client. Notably, the visualization of the counterfactual distance space, employed by our Federated Behavioural Shields, effectively identifies the malicious client. It indicates a high distance of the attacker from all other clients, leading to a low score during the aggregation process. To further validate our approach, we compared the performance of our Federated Behavioural Shields under No-attack, Crafted-noise, Inverted-gradient, Label-flipping, and Inverted-loss attacks in both IID and non-IID settings. Table 3 demonstrates that higher accuracy is achieved in the IID setting under almost all conditions compared to the non-IID setting, underscoring the increased complexity of operating in non-IID environments.

references: We conducted an ablation study to examine the impact of various components on the efficacy of our algorithm. These components include predictive performance (error), decision-making process (counterfactuals), and the application of a moving average. Table 4 presents the average accuracy and standard error under five experimental conditions: No-attack, Crafted-noise, Inverted-gradient, Label-flipping, and Inverted-loss, comparing different variations of our method against baselines on the Breast Cancer and Diabetes datasets.

. This quantitative analysis aims to supplement the visual data presented, offering precise values and statistical insights that underpin the observations and conclusions discussed throughout the paper. Tables

for small-MNIST present a comprehensive comparison of our Federated Behavioural Shields and its streamlined versions using only the CBP or the EBP. These are evaluated against traditional defenses such as Krum, Median, and Trimmed-mean across five scenarios: No attack, Crafted-noise, Inverted-gradient, Label-flipping, and Inverted-loss. This comparison elucidates the effectiveness of our approach under a range of conditions, both adversarial and non-adversarial.
